thread.section_title: SF Bay area and California politics and policy - San Francisco Chronicle
thread.title: House leader links Benghazi probe to attempt to stop Clinton run
thread.title_full: House leader links Benghazi probe to attempt to stop Clinton run - San Francisco Chronicle

author: Carolyn Lochhead
title: House leader links Benghazi probe to attempt to stop Clinton run
text:
Photo: Jacquelyn Martin, Associated Press House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy of Calif., center, walks to a procedural vote and debate in the House on a stopgap spending bill to avert a government shutdown, Wednesday, Sept. 30, 2015, on Capitol Hill in Washington. A temporary funding measure aiming to keep the government open past a midnight deadline sailed through the Senate on Wednesday and was expected to make its way shortly through a divided House and on to President Barack Obama. (AP Photo/Jacquelyn Martin) House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy of Calif., center, walks to a...
WASHINGTON — Kevin McCarthy, the Bakersfield Republican poised to lead the House of Representatives, came under fire Wednesday for linking the $4.5 million investigation of the Benghazi attacks to Hillary Rodham Clinton’s poll numbers, candidly indicating that the real motive for the longest-running probe in congressional history has been to damage the top Democratic contender for president. House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy of Calif., center, walks to a procedural vote and debate in the House on a stopgap spending bill to avert a government shutdown, Wednesday, Sept. 30, 2015, on Capitol Hill in Washington. A temporary funding measure aiming to keep the government open past a midnight deadline sailed through the Senate on Wednesday and was expected to make its way shortly through a divided House and on to President Barack Obama. (AP Photo/Jacquelyn Martin) House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy of Calif., center, walks to a...
WASHINGTON — Kevin McCarthy, the Bakersfield Republican poised to lead the House of Representatives, came under fire Wednesday for linking the $4.5 million investigation of the Benghazi attacks to Hillary Rodham Clinton’s poll numbers, candidly indicating that the real motive for the longest-running probe in congressional history has been to damage the top Democratic contender for president.
